Introduction

Neonatal conjunctivitis, also known as ophthalmia neonatorum, is inflammation of the conjunctiva that occurs during the first 4 weeks of life.  It can be caused by infectious or noninfectious etiologies.

Pathophysiology and risk factors



Neonatal conjunctivitis most commonly occurs due to infection.  Although bacteria and viruses that commonly cause conjunctivitis in older patients (eg, Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus pneumoniae, adenovirus) can also affect neonates, Neisseria gonorrhoeae and Chlamydia trachomatis are pathogens unique to the neonatal period and can cause severe complications.  These infections are acquired by vertical transmission via contact with infected maternal genital secretions during vaginal delivery.  Following transmission, the bacteria invade the conjunctival epithelium, prompting an inflammatory response.



Risk factors include:



  • Lack of prenatal care/routine screening for sexually transmitted infections (STIs)
  • Prolonged rupture of membranes during labor
  • Lack of prophylactic topical erythromycin at birth (prevents only gonococcal conjunctivitis)


Less commonly, neonatal conjunctivitis can occur due to noninfectious etiologies (eg, exposure to chemical irritants) which can sometimes develop as an adverse effect of topical medications (eg, erythromycin ointment).

Clinical presentation



The clinical presentation of neonatal conjunctivitis depends on whether the underlying etiology is noninfectious or infectious:



  • Noninfectious (ie, chemical):  Typically presents with mild conjunctival injection and tearing in the first 24 hours of life.
  • Infectious:  Typically presents with eyelid edema, purulent eye discharge, and conjunctival injection and edema (ie, chemosis); the timing of the symptoms helps distinguish the causative organism:
    • Gonococcal (

    • Chlamydial (

      ):  Presents at age 5-14 days.  The discharge may initially be scant and watery before becoming purulent; occasionally, it may become bloody due to friable conjunctivae (a specific finding for Chlamydia conjunctivitis).


Because chlamydial and gonococcal conjunctivitis can present similarly, the patient's age at symptom onset is a key distinguishing feature.

Diagnosis



Diagnosis of neonatal conjunctivitis involves a thorough history, physical examination, and laboratory evaluation.  A detailed maternal history, including prenatal care and STI screening, is essential.  Ophthalmic examination may show eyelid edema, conjunctival injection and edema, exudate, and corneal ulceration.



If there is clinical suspicion for an infectious cause, pparticularly if there are risk factors for maternal STI, exudates should be sampled for laboratory evaluation.  Nucleic acid amplification testing is the gold standard for diagnosis of chlamydial and gonococcal conjunctivitis.  Because C trachomatis is an obligate intracellular organism, the specimen must contain conjunctival epithelial cells and should be obtained from the everted eyelid.  For suspected gonococcal conjunctivitis, the exudate should also be sent for Gram stain (which can show gram-negative intracellular diplococci (

image 1
)) and culture using Thayer-Martin medium.



Testing for other possible causative organisms (eg, S aureus, Haemophilus influenzae, S pneumoniae, herpes simplex virus) should be considered in addition to testing for chlamydial and gonococcal infections.

Management



Empiric antibiotic therapy can be initiated in patients with pending laboratory test results if the history and physical examination are consistent with neonatal conjunctivitis, as follows:



  • Chlamydial conjunctivitis can be treated with an oral macrolide (eg, azithromycin).  Topical therapy for chlamydial conjunctivitis has a high failure rate and is therefore not effective.  Of note, oral macrolides are associated with an increased risk of pyloric stenosis in infants age <2 weeks.  Therefore, these patients should be monitored closely for signs of intestinal obstruction (eg, immediate projectile vomiting after feeds).
  • Gonococcal conjunctivitis can be treated with an intravenous (IV) or intramuscular (IM) third-generation cephalosporin (eg, cefotaxime, ceftriaxone).  Ceftriaxone should be avoided in patients requiring treatment for hyperbilirubinemia (eg, phototherapy) because it displaces bilirubin from albumin, thereby increasing the risk of neurotoxicity.


Patients should receive serial eye irrigation until a clinical response is observed.  Patients should also be monitored closely for complications, such as corneal involvement (which can lead to ulceration) and systemic spread of infection.

Prognosis



With prompt diagnosis and treatment, the prognosis for neonatal conjunctivitis is favorable.  However, delayed or inadequate treatment can lead to severe complications, including corneal ulceration, scarring, and blindness.



Patients with untreated chlamydial conjunctivitis are also at increased risk for chlamydial pneumonia, which typically presents with staccato cough and rales in an afebrile patient at age 4-12 weeks.

Prevention



The most effective way to prevent N gonorrhoeae or C trachomatis infection in the neonate is to diagnose and treat maternal infections during pregnancy, thereby minimizing the risk of vertical transmission during vaginal delivery.



Accordingly, preventive measures include:



  • Prenatal care, including routine screening for STIs
  • Prompt treatment for patients with positive screening for STIs and their sexual partners
  • Education and counseling regarding the importance of compliance with STI prevention and treatment
  • Prophylactic erythromycin ophthalmic ointment for all newborns, including those whose mothers tested negative or were treated for gonorrhea (due to the possibility of reinfection)

Summary



Neonatal conjunctivitis (
